abstract.text: 250 Text: 7,976 Running title: Replication-competent controlled herpesvirus vectors ABSTRACT 1

Replication-competent controlled virus vectors were derived from virulent HSV-1 2 wildtype strain 17syn+ by placing one or two replication-essential genes under the 3 stringent control of a gene switch that is co-activated by heat and an antiprogestin. 4 Upon activation of the gene switch, the vectors replicate in infected cells with an efficacy 5 that approaches that of the wildtype virus from which they were derived. Essentially no 6 replication occurs in the absence of activation. When administered to mice, localized 7 application of a transient heat treatment in the presence of systemic antiprogestin 8 results in efficient but limited virus replication at the site of administration. The 9 immunogenicity of these viral vectors was tested in a mouse footpad lethal challenge 10 model. Unactivated viral vectors -which may be regarded as equivalents of inactivated 11 vaccines -induced detectable protection against lethality caused by wildtype virus 12 challenge. Single activation of the viral vectors at the site of administration (rear 13 footpads) greatly enhanced protective immune responses, and second immunization 14 resulted in complete protection. Once activated vectors also induced far better 15 neutralizing antibody and HSV-1-specific T cells responses than unactivated vectors.

body_text.text: We hypothesized that vigorous replication of a pathogen may be critical for eliciting the 2 most potent and balanced immune response against it. Hence, attenuation/inactivation 3 (as in conventional vaccines) should be avoided. Instead, necessary safety should be 4 provided by placing replication of the pathogen under stringent control and of activating 5 time-limited replication of the pathogen strictly in an administration region in which 6 pathology cannot develop. Immunization will then occur in the context of highly efficient 7 pathogen replication and uncompromised safety. We found that localized activation in 8 mice of efficient but limited replication of a replication-competent controlled herpesvirus 9 vector resulted in a greatly enhanced immune response to the virus or an expressed 10 heterologous antigen. This finding supports the above hypothesis as well as suggests 11 that the vectors may be promising novel agents worth exploring for the 12 prevention/mitigation of infectious diseases for which efficient vaccination is lacking, in 13 particular in immunocompromised patients.

that attenuated replicating viruses induce more complete and more potent immune 1 responses to autologous or heterologous antigens than corresponding non-replicating 2 viruses. 3 We hypothesized that a virus vector that could replicate in a controlled fashion with 4 nearly the same efficiency as the respective wildtype virus (referred to herein as 5 "replication-competent controlled virus vector") would induce an even more potent and 6 complete immune response to itself or an expressed heterologous antigen than a 7 corresponding attenuated vector (26). Our hypothesis is in part based on the rational 8 expectation that an efficiently replicating virus will produce a stronger inflammatory 9 response than an attenuated virus, which inflammatory response will result in a potent 10 activation of the innate immune system and, consequently, in strong and lasting B and T 11 cell responses (27) . To realize such an immunization strategy, a regulation system must 12 be employed that reliably and stringently controls viral replication as well as is capable 13 of being turned on and off at will. However, virus disseminates after administration. 14 Simply restricting the number of replication cycles will not be enough: depending on the 15 number of cycles allowed, there will be a more or less pronounced manifestation of the 16 toxicity typical for the viral vector used. For example, allowing an HSV-1 vector to 17 replicate for a certain period of time may cause unacceptable neurotoxicity. Hence, the 18 regulation system must be capable of exerting regional control over viral replication so 19 that the immunizing virus only replicates in a locale in which it is certain not to cause a 20 disease phenotype. FIGREF13.text: 12 regarded as a first illustration of the principle. In general, any of a number of DNA 13 viruses including members of all herpesvirus subfamilies may be employed for the 14 construction of replication-competent controlled vectors. We selected a fully virulent 15 HSV-1 strain as the backbone of the GS vectors for several reasons, including that HSV 16 have a double-stranded DNA genome that does not integrate in the host genome and 17 are tolerant of sizeable insertions, support stable expression of heterologous genes, 18 replicate and lyse cells efficiently as well as respond to antiviral drugs (37-40). Although 19 HSV are endemic in the human population, available data indicate that pre-existing 20 immunity is not an obstacle to vaccination/immunization uses of HSV vectors 21 (discussed in ref. 34). Furthermore, latent infection was considered a manageable issue 22 because replication of replication-competent controlled vectors can be stringently 23 controlled, and reactivation should not be capable of occurring in the two-component HSP promoter-based gene switch that is used for 3 controlling viral replication, several ligand-dependent transactivators are known that 4 may be considered for incorporation in such a gene switch. They include transactivators 5 that are derived from the bacterial tetracycline repressor or other bacterial repressors as 6 well as chimeric transactivators that exploit ligand-binding domains of various steroid 7 receptors, e.g., human progesterone, human estrogen or insect ecdysone receptors, or 8 are activated by dimerization (28). We previously constructed and analyzed two-9 component HSP promoter-based gene switches that are co-activated by antiprogestins, 10 ecdysteroid ponasterone A and rapamycin/rapalog, respectively (31,41). For regulating 11 the HSV-GS vectors, we made use of a heat-and antiprogestin-activated gene switch 12 that is strictly dependent on both heat and antiprogestin. While it has been more 13 thoroughly characterized than any other (31), this gene switch also recommends itself 14 for several other reasons. It comprises transactivator GLP65 that is activated by a 15 narrow spectrum of antiprogestins but not progestins (34). Since it only includes a 16 truncated ligand-binding domain of a progesterone receptor, GLP65 should not be 17 susceptible to ligand-independent activation; in fact, after many years of experimental 18 use, no antiprogestin-independent activation has been reported. At the low doses at 19 which they activate GLP65, antiprogestins such as mifepristone and ulipristal are not 20 expected to have any negative effects on the immune system (26). The latter 21antiprogestins also have been safety-tested in human subjects as well as are readily 22 available. They are not considered essential active ingredients by the WHO, and their 23 primary use has been in emergency contraception. To maintain maximal safety GS-type vector. In contrast, the HSV-GS vectors 6 may be well suited as immunization agents or platforms in middle-aged or elderly 7 subjects. It is noted that it may be feasible to disable replication of fully activated HSV-8 GS vectors in latently infected cells through further engineering.

FIGREF14.text: Replication-competent controlled virus vectors may be capable of making a unique10 contribution to immunization of immunocompromised patients. A recent study estimated 11 that in 2012 over 3% of the adult populations of the United States and the United 12 Kingdom were immunocompromised (42). Frequencies in other upper-income countries 13 are expected to be comparable. These patients are particularly vulnerable to vaccine-14 preventable disease and would greatly benefit from effective vaccination. Owing to their 15 condition, their immune response to inactivated or subunit vaccines may be inadequate. 16 Unfortunately, use of live attenuated vaccines that may produce a more balanced and 17 more persistent immune response is problematic because of the perceived danger that 18 such vaccines may be insufficiently controlled by the weakened immune system and 19 may cause the disease they are intended to prevent. According to most relevant 20 guidelines, live attenuated vaccines are contraindicated in patients under 21 immunosuppressive therapy or HIV patients with low CD4 count (43). Hence, use of 22 currently marketed vaccines against tuberculosis (BCG), measles, mumps and rubella, 23 varicella-zoster, rotavirus, influenza (nasal) and yellow fever is universally discouraged. virus vectors expressing antigens of the latter microbes in the 4 context of efficient viral replication can be expected to elicit similarly or more potent 5 immune reactions as the contraindicated live attenuated vaccines. Escape from immune 6 control will not be an issue because expression of replication-essential genes is under 7 stringent dual control. Hence, replication of the vectors can be activated and safely 8 disactivated independent of the immune status of a patient.

Juxtaposing DISC viruses and replication-competent controlled viruses, the 15 latter viruses replicate nearly as efficiently as the wildtype virus that had been used for 16 their construction. No comparable information is available for the DISC viruses that 17 were advanced as vaccine candidates. Replication of DISC viruses is not localized but 18 occurs throughout the host. Depending on the dose of virus administered, a single 19 round of replication of disseminated virus can be expected to result in significant 20 toxicity. Not surprisingly, intracranial administration of DISC virus TA-HSV resulted in 21neurotoxicity that was only about two orders of magnitude lower than that of the 22 wildtype virus from which the strain was derived (46). Replication-competent controlled viruses should be devoid of such toxicity because they are virtually incapable of 1 replicating unless deliberately activated. It is noted that the stringency of the replication 2 block can be increased further by subjecting additional replication-essential genes to 3 gene switch control. Furthermore, even though progeny virus produced by a DISC virus 4 upon immunization is not supposed to be capable of re-infecting cells, latent infection 5 has been observed (46). Latent infection is known to involve spread from cell to cell 6 (47). Hence, as has been pointed out before (48), DISC viruses such as TA-HSV7 appear to be leaky for replication in vivo. The above properties of DISC viruses are not 8 desirable in an immunization agent or vector administered to healthy people and would 9 disqualify such viruses from use in persons with impaired immune systems. It is noted 10 that a clinical trial was conducted that investigated a DISC virus as a therapeutic 11 vaccine against recurrent genital herpes (49). Results were negative. The DISC virus 12 (TA-HSV) studied had been derived from a minimally virulent HSV-2 wildtype strain 13 (46,50). Moreover, the virus was administered at a relatively low dose, apparently to 14 avoid toxicity. Failure of the trial should not be very surprising. 15 Unlike a conventional vaccine, a replication-competent controlled vector will need to be 16 activated after administration to a subject to be immunized.
